justification: “Measures of objective numeracy, such as the Rasch-based numeracy scale (Weller et al., 2013)… require people to calculate to solve math problems.”
“Measures of objective numeracy, such as…the Berlin numeracy scale (Cokely et al., 2012) require people to calculate to solve math problems.”

“Health decision-making researchers also rely on the subjective numeracy scale (Fagerlin et al., 2007) to measure self-reported math ability without the need for participants to calculate their answers.”

“Researchers should specifically consider number-line estimation tasks with fractions because rational number understanding is crucial for interpreting health statistics…performance on fraction number-line estimation tasks has been shown to be correlated with…overall math achievement.”
“Math anxiety can be reliably assessed with one item (see Ashcraft, 2002; Núñez-Peña et al., 2014).”
